item.title: Middle East Crisis: Hamas Leader Mourned in Qatar With Middle East on Edge
item.description: Ismail Haniyeh, the political leader of Hamas who was assassinated earlier this week, was being buried in Qatar. President Biden expressed deep concern about the situation in the region, and called on Israel to agree to a cease-fire in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Israel Confirms Death of Muhammad Deif, Who It Says Helped Planned Hamas Attack
item.description: The Israeli military said it had killed Muhammad Deif, who it called a planner of the Oct. 7 attack on Israel, which would make him the third Iranian-backed militant leader slain in recent days.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Farnaz Fassihi, Euan Ward and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hezbollah supporters on Thursday carried the coffin of a commander, Fuad Shukr, who was killed in an Israeli airstrike in the southern suburbs of Beirut.

item.title: Evan Gershkovich and 23 Others Freed From Russian Prisons in Major Swap
item.description: The Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich was among 24 people released in a seven-nation, painstakingly negotiated deal that President Biden hailed as a triumph of diplomacy.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Mark Mazzetti
item.media:description: Evan Gershkovich inside an enclosure for defendants before a court hearing in Yekaterinburg, Russia, in June.

item.title: U.S. Recognizes Edmundo Gonz√°lez as Winner of Venezuela Election
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said there was ‚Äúoverwhelming evidence‚Äù that Edmundo Gonz√°lez had won, despite President Nicol√°s Maduro‚Äôs claim of victory.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Edmundo Gonz√°lez, the opposition presidential candidate, wearing a blue shirt, stood next to Mar√≠a Corina Machado, a popular opposition leader, at a rally in Caracas, Venezuela, on Tuesday.

item.title: Kremlin Confirms Assassin Vadim Krasikov Is an Agent for Russia‚Äôs FSB
item.description: Vadim Krasikov, who was returned to Russia in the big prisoner swap, received a hero‚Äôs welcome from President Putin, along with others who were freed.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: In a photo released by Russian state media, President Vladimir V. Putin greets Vadim Krasikov at Vnukovo International Airport outside Moscow on Thursday.

item.title: Behind the Prisoner Swap: Spies, a Killer, Secret Messages and Unseen Diplomacy
item.description: The negotiations that led to the prisoner swap and the freeing of Americans wrongfully held in Russia required patience and creativity, but gave both sides what they wanted most.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti, Anton Troianovski, Michael D. Shear and Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris greeting the Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich, a prisoner freed by Russia, as he arrived at Joint Base Andrews.

item.title: Vault + bars + beam + floor = gold for Simone Biles.
item.description: Here‚Äôs a look at how Simone Biles won the gymnastics all-around gold medal, one routine at a time.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor, Gabriela Bhaskar, Chang W. Lee and Daniel Berehulak

item.title: Hundreds of Prisoners in Russia, Including Americans, Were Left Behind in Swap
item.description: Hundreds of prisoners ‚Äî including Americans and Russian political activists ‚Äî are hoping for a diplomatic agreement that might secure their release.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Anne Fogel, right, reads a letter written by her brother, Marc Fogel, during a rally advocating for his release in Washington in July 2023.

item.title: Winzar Kakiouea Is a One-Man Team From Nauru. His Olympics Might be Over in 10 Seconds.
item.description: Winzar Kakiouea, a 100-meter runner, is the only competitor at the Paris Games from his Pacific island nation. His debut might be over in a flash.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Winzar Kakiouea will compete in the 100-meter heats on Saturday.

item.title: Pakistanis Rise Up Against Ruling Elite as Misery Multiplies
item.description: Unrest over a range of economic and security issues threatens to deepen the political turmoil that has plagued Pakistan for years.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Salman Masood
item.media:description: A protest against higher electricity bills in Karachi, Pakistan, in July.

item.title: Many of Gaza‚Äôs Medical Workers Have Been Detained or Killed
item.description: Out of a prewar total of about 20,000 health workers, 500 have been killed in the war, according to the W.H.O., and more than 300 are in Israeli detention, Gaza‚Äôs health ministry says.
item.dc:creator: Anjana Sankar
item.media:description: A doctor inspecting damage at Nasser Hospital, in Khan Younis.

item.title: Fears of Wider Mideast Conflict Deepen, With U.S. Seen as ‚ÄòNot in Control‚Äô
item.description: American officials said they had no advance warning of the attack on the Hamas leader in Iran, raising worries of a power vacuum that could lead to a broader geopolitical crisis.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: People in Tehran on Wednesday held Iranian and Palestinian flags and images of Ismail Haniyeh, the Hamas leader who was killed in the city that morning.

item.title: Teenage Talent at the 2024 Olympics
item.description: From the shooting range to the swimming pool, teens and preteens are grabbing medals and the spotlight. Nowhere is this truer than at the skateboard park.
item.dc:creator: Dodai Stewart
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vareeraya Sukasem, 12, of Thailand in the warm-up before the heats of the women‚Äôs street skateboarding competition at La Concorde in Paris.

item.title: Champagne, Soft Piano and No Lines: Luxe Life at the Olympics
item.description: A new program allows spectators at the Paris Games to upgrade their seats, eat tastier food, tip glasses of bubbly and avoid the throngs.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Spectators in the V.I.P. area of a men‚Äôs beach volleyball match on Monday. Those with thousands of euros to spend can sit, eat and travel apart from the masses.

item.title: U.S. Is Preparing to Send More Combat Aircraft to the Middle East, Officials Say
item.description: How many planes to send is still being worked out, as are final approvals from senior officials including Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Why Some Young People in China Pretend to Be Birds
item.description: Some young people in China pretend to be birds on social media as way of escaping hustle culture. We can explain.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang

item.title: At a Mountain Retreat, Wine, Lamb Kebabs and Lots of Climate Talk
item.description: Azerbaijan last week convened a special meeting of climate diplomats at a remote resort. A Times reporter was there.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak and Nanna Heitmann
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Diplomats at the Heads of Delegation retreat were tasked with determining how to disburse huge amounts of money to fight global warming and compensate poor and vulnerable countries that suffer its worst effects.

item.title: Inside Azerbaijan, Host of COP29
item.description: In Azerbaijan, the causes and effects of climate change are on vivid display and the painful trade-offs needed to fight it are acutely felt.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak and Nanna Heitmann
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times

item.title: Talking Trump and Economics With Joseph Stiglitz in Sydney
item.description: His new book is about reimagining freedom for ‚Äòprogressive capitalism.‚Äô
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: Joseph E. Stiglitz, a Nobel-winning economist, in Barcelona, Spain, in 2023.

item.title: Talking Trump and Economics With Joseph Stiglitz in Sydney
item.description: The eminent economist describes Donald Trump and the MAGA movement as a response to the failure of nearly 40 years of neoliberalism.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: Joseph E. Stiglitz, a Nobel-winning economist, in Barcelona, Spain, in 2023.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: A sweeping prisoner swap between Russia and the West.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: President Biden embracing Evan Gershkovich, the Wall Street Journal reporter, at Joint Base Andrews in Maryland as Kamala Harris looks on.

item.title: With Russia Prisoner Swap, Biden Scores a Win Near the End of His Term
item.description: The exchange offered a measure of validation for President Biden soon after he abandoned his bid for re-election.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Biden announced on Thursday at the White House that three American citizens and a U.S. permanent resident freed by Russia were heading home, as their families stood beside him.

item.title: Air Force Finds Mechanical and Crew Failures in Fatal Osprey Crash Last Year
item.description: An investigation determined that missed warning signals and the ‚Äúcatastrophic failure‚Äù of a gearbox led to the crash off the coast of Japan in November.
item.dc:creator: Aishvarya Kavi
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Pieces of a crashed U.S. military Osprey aircraft recovered by a military salvage ship in southwestern Japan last December.

item.title: MrBeast Acknowledges ‚ÄòInappropriate Language‚Äô in Earlier Videos
item.description: A representative for the popular YouTuber said that he was ‚Äútrying to be funny‚Äù and made ‚Äúbad jokes‚Äù in older videos of him that have resurfaced.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jim√©nez
item.media:description: The YouTube personality Jimmy Donaldson, better known as MrBeast, at the Nickelodeon Kids‚Äô Choice Awards in Los Angeles last year.

item.title: Katie Ledecky‚Äôs 13th Olympic medal is a silver, but one for the record books.
item.description: No female American Olympian has won more medals than Ledecky, who swam the third leg for the Americans‚Äô 4x200 freestyle relay team that finished second behind Australia.
item.dc:creator: Ben Shpigel, James Hill and Karen Hanley
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times

item.title: Friday Briefing: Evan Gershkovich Freed in a Prisoner Swap
item.description: Plus, how a Hamas leader was assassinated in Iran and a look inside the Olympic Village.
item.dc:creator: Whet Moser
item.media:credit: Russian Federal Security Service/RTR, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Evan Gershkovich on a plane leaving Russia, in an image from video footage provided by the Russian Federal Security Service.

item.title: Evan Gershkovich Was Caught in Oppression His Parents Had Fled
item.description: Evan Gershkovich was raised in New Jersey by parents who left the Soviet Union to escape antisemitism and a lack of opportunity.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: Evan Gershkovich inside an enclosure for defendants before a court hearing in June in Yekaterinburg, Russia.

item.title: Turkey Revels in the Role It Played in Prisoner Swap
item.description: Turkey has frustrated its NATO allies by often refusing to get tough with Russia, but its good relations with Moscow may have helped it participate in the exchange.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Safak Timur
item.media:description: A Russian plane leaving Ankara Esenboga Airport in Ankara, Turkey, after a major prisoner exchange between Russia, the United States and other countries on Thursday.

item.title: Hezbollah Leader Threatens Retaliation Against Israel After Airstrike Near Beirut
item.description: Nasrallah delivered a televised address at the funeral of a Hezbollah commander who was killed in an Israeli strike in suburban Beirut.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The leader of the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah, Hassan Nasrallah, seen on a video screen at the funeral for Fuad Shukr, a Hezbollah commander, in Beirut, Lebanon, on Thursday.

item.title: Who Is Vadim Krasikov, the Russian Exchanged for a U.S. Reporter?
item.description: Vadim Krasikov was sentenced to life in prison in Germany for a brazen assassination in a downtown park in Berlin. Now he is free.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: A photo distributed by the Berlin police showed the primary suspect in the assassination of a former Chechen separatist fighter. He carried a passport identifying himself as Vadim A. Sokolov. He was later identified as Vadim N. Krasikov,

item.title: How Golf and Physics Are Raising the Limits in Shot-Put
item.description: Ryan Crouser, an American, has combined radar technology borrowed from golf and an innovative technique to take aim at his third straight Olympic gold.
item.dc:creator: Jer√© Longman
item.media:description: Ryan Crouser at the U.S. track and field trials in June. He holds the world record in the shot-put.

item.title: Turkey Aims to Cull Its Stray Dogs. Critics Say It‚Äôs About Politics.
item.description: Turkey‚Äôs new law aimed at moving millions of stray dogs to shelters, and allowing some to be euthanized, has both cultural and political implications.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Hurtes
item.media:description: A stray dog resting in front of Hagia Sophia in Istanbul, in May.

item.title: Who Was Freed in the Prisoner Swap Between Russia and the West?
item.description: Here‚Äôs a list of the 24 prisoners who were exchanged on Thursday and their backgrounds.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko, Valerie Hopkins and Alina Lobzina

item.title: Italian Boxer Angela Carini Quits Olympic Bout, Sparking Gender Furor
item.description: The Italian, Angela Carini, stopped fighting only 46 seconds into her matchup against Imane Khelif of Algeria, who had been barred from a women‚Äôs event last year.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja and Jer√© Longman
item.media:description: Imane Khelif of Algeria is declared the winner after Angela Carini of Italy abandoned their Olympic boxing match in Paris.

item.title: Who Are the Most Prominent People Released in the Russia Prisoner Swap?
item.description: The prisoners released on Thursday include a Wall Street Journal reporter, an editor working for Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty and a former U.S. Marine who had served in Iraq.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: Evan Gershkovich stood in a glass defendants‚Äô cage before a hearing in June.

item.title: Sprouts Spotted by the Stump of the Sycamore Gap Tree
item.description: Vandals last year chopped down the famed tree, which had stood on Hadrian‚Äôs Wall in England for nearly 200 years.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: The Sycamore Gap tree, a beloved way marker, had grown for centuries along Hadrian‚Äôs Wall in England before vandals cut it down last year. Now little shoots have been discovered growing at its stump.

item.title: Famine Declared in Darfur Region of Sudan
item.description: Experts who monitor global hunger rarely make an official declaration of famine, but they just sounded the alarm for more than half a million people who have fled the fighting in Sudan‚Äôs civil war.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Women and children at the Zamzam displacement camp, close to El Fasher in North Darfur, Sudan, in January.

item.title: How Hamas Leader Ismail Haniyeh Was Killed in Iran
item.description: An explosive device hidden in a heavily guarded complex where Ismail Haniyeh was known to stay in Iran was what killed him, according to a Times investigation.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Mark Mazzetti and Farnaz Fassihi

item.title: South Korea Offers Humanitarian Aid to Flood-Stricken North Korea
item.description: If accepted, the help could lead to the first official dialogue in years between the two Koreas, which have recently been sending each other trash balloons and propaganda.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse ‚Äî Getty Images
item.media:description: A photograph provided by North Korean state media shows flooding in the city of Sinuiju, North Korea, on Sunday.

item.title: Suspect in Southport Stabbings Is Named
item.description: A judge allowed the naming of the 17-year-old charged with murder, as Prime Minister Keir Starmer vowed a crackdown on riots fueled by far-right misinformation.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Protesters remonstrate with police officers during a demonstration on Whitehall, outside the entrance to Downing Street in central London on July 31.

item.title: Security Concerns Grow for Israeli Olympians in Paris
item.description: Concerns for the Israeli team ‚Äî which has been shrouded in protection at every Games since 1972 ‚Äî have substantially increased since the Oct. 7 terrorist attacks and the war in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg and Johnatan Reiss
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Security officers before a soccer game last week at the Olympics in Paris.

item.title: Elon Musk Blasts Venezuela‚Äôs Maduro in an Escalating War of Words
item.description: Mr. Musk, who has long criticized leftist politicians, called President Nicol√°s Maduro a ‚Äúdictator‚Äù and compared him to a donkey.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac and Simon Romero
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs go for it, Elon Musk,‚Äù said President Nicol√°s Maduro, shown on Wednesday during a news conference in Caracas.

item.title: As Botanists Drop a Racist Plant Name, Some Fear Scientific Confusion
item.description: The International Botanical Congress voted to change a scientific name belonging to hundreds of plant species because it was offensive in southern Africa.
item.dc:creator: Clarissa Brincat

item.title: Like Cyclists in a Peloton, Schooling Fish Save Energy, Study Finds
item.description: Like Olympic cyclists, fish expend less effort when swimming in tight groups than when alone. The finding could explain why some species evolved to move in schools.
item.dc:creator: Katrina Miller

item.title: How Olympic Injuries Break Bodies
item.description: With years of fractures, surgeries, hardware and pain, Olympians can list their injuries as readily as their achievements.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mariana Paj√≥n, a Colombian BMX rider, showing a scar from among her many surgeries.

item.title: Muhammad Deif, a Top Hamas Commander, Is Dead, Israel Says
item.description: Mr. Deif has survived several previous Israeli assassination attempts and has been the No. 2 Hamas leader in Gaza. Israel said it killed him in a strike last month in southern Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Aaron Boxerman

item.title: For Simone Biles, a Long Road Back Is Paved in Gold
item.description: After winning the all-around gymnastics title, she wore a sparkly necklace in the shape of a goat, for Greatest of All Time. But she is not done yet: She has three more chances to win medals in Paris.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.description: Fears of escalation in the Middle East.

item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Professors in Tehran protesting the killing of Ismail Haniyeh.

item.title: Can Gouda‚Äôs Cheesemakers Stall a Sinking Future?
item.description: The small city where the renowned Dutch cheese is made is subsiding as sea levels rise. Experts say the industry may not survive there, even with the ingenuity of the country‚Äôs water managers.
item.dc:creator: Nina Siegal
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ad van Kluijve selling his cheeses at the weekly market in Gouda, the Netherlands.

item.title: In an Italian Village, a Mayor Walks Off the Wine and Everyone Joins In
item.description: Luciano Fregonese, the mayor of a town in Italy known for Prosecco, started walking to counter the calories he consumed at social obligations. His jaunts have become a sensation.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:description: Luciano Fregonese, center, in a white shirt, on a stroll through the town with his constituents and other walking enthusiasts.

item.title: Nancy Martiny‚Äôs Saddles Have a Six-Year Wait Time
item.description: Nancy Martiny‚Äôs ornate pieces, which sell for $5,000 and up, are meant to be ridden by working cowboys and cowgirls like herself.
item.dc:creator: Susan Shain and Sasha Arutyunova
item.media:credit: Sasha Arutyunova for The New York Times

item.title: Ex-Green Beret Goudreau, Who Planned Failed Venezuela Coup, Is Arrested
item.description: Jordan Goudreau, 48, had taken credit for a failed coup attempt against Nicol√°s Maduro of Venezuela. He faces federal charges of illegal arms smuggling.

item.title: Iran‚Äôs Options for Retaliation Risk Escalating Middle East Crisis
item.description: The killing of Hamas‚Äôs political leader in Tehran was a humiliating security failure for the Iranian government.

item.title: Assassination of a top Hamas leader spurs rallies worldwide.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni

item.title: Iran and Hamas Blame Israel for Killing of Ismail Haniyeh, and Vow Revenge
item.description: The deadly strike on Ismail Haniyeh in Tehran threatened to further inflame the region and derail negotiations aimed at reaching a cease-fire in Gaza.

item.title: See the Moment Katie Ledecky Won Gold in the 1500-Meter Freestyle
item.description: Katie Ledecky comfortably won the 1,500-meter freestyle, beating her winning time from the Tokyo Games by more than seven seconds.

item.title: Two Al Jazeera Journalists Were Killed in an Israeli Strike on Gaza
item.description: A reporter and a cameraman were working from or near the house of Ismail Haniyeh, the Hamas political chief who was assassinated on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Palestinians inspect a vehicle where Al Jazeera TV said its reporter Ismail al-Ghoul and cameraman Ramy El Rify were killed in an Israeli strike, in Gaza City July 31, 2024.

item.title: Iran‚Äôs Leader Orders Attack on Israel for Haniyeh Killing, Officials Say
item.description: Iran‚Äôs supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, ordered retaliation after a humiliating security failure, as Iran once again balances showing strength against the risk of escalation.

item.media:description: Images of Ismail Haniyeh, a senior Hamas leader who was assassinated in Iran on Wednesday, at a square in Tehran.

item.title: Election Results Presented by Venezuela‚Äôs Opposition Suggest Maduro Lost Decisively
item.description: The Times analyzed partial voting tallies collected by the opposition. They cast further doubt on Nicol√°s Maduro‚Äôs declared victory.

item.title: How Henrik Christiansen Made Chocolate Muffins a Hit at the Olympics
item.description: On a quest to fuel himself with thousands of calories a day, Henrik Christiansen found an unexpected delight and shared it with the world.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin

item.title: Robot Captures Pictures of the Dotson Ice Shelf in Antarctica
item.description: The new images of the melting underside of an ice shelf could help scientists better forecast how the continent is contributing to rising sea levels.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong

item.title: Guinea Court Finds Former President Guilty of Stadium Massacre and Rapes
item.description: The West African nation‚Äôs former leader and some of his top aides were found guilty of crimes against humanity for mass murder and rapes committed during and after a pro-democracy protest in 2009.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean and Abdourahmane Diallo
